revised_title: Secondary Length Changes in Experimentally Deformed Rocks: Marble and Limestone
tldr: This study investigates the secondary changes in length of marble and limestone after deformation at high pressure. The results show that after compression, the specimens tend to elongate more than undeformed specimens, while after extension, the length changes are less. These departures from normal elastic behavior are mainly due to intergranular stresses, which cause grain distortion and the opening of internal fractures. The findings have implications for understanding phenomena involving diffusion and the interpretation of experimental work in geology.
